comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: As noted that's definitely the market on the Coal Quay. The view (in particular when the stalls are out) hasn't actually changed that much to today. (Note that the building on the left with the columns is now a pub. It and some of the surrounding buildings were site of the indoor St Peters Market from the 1840s. It was often called the Irish Market. To distinguish it from the English Market off the Grand Parade. They have a piece on the pub website which gives a little potted history.) Not sure how to be more concrete about the date.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: The Durrus/West Cork history blog has a smashing photo of the market (same time period) from the Library of Congress collection. It's more of a character study than the Lawrence collection pano. (Spot yer great-granny anyone?) (EDIT: URL blocking issues? See: loc.gov/pictures/resource/cph.3b15531/)

comment.author: 59941010@N06
comment._content: This is a brilliant old photo of Cornmarket Street locally called "the coal quay pronounced coal kay". It looked like this when I was a child, I love the women in shawls [the shawlies]. Thanks for sharing such wonderful photos. Here's a look at it today from the same spot. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/dorameulman/6478657915/in/set-72157627769738314]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Marvellous photo. Red Herring (which I did not know previously) - Sydney, Australia also has a much-loved Paddy's Market since 1834 - "It was an Irish tradition - hence the name "Paddy's" - and it was only natural that it should be constituted a new in a colony that had received 30,000 male and 9000 female convicts directly from Ireland, as well as thousands of Irish immigrants from places like Liverpool." from www.paddysmarkets.com.au/history.html

comment.author: 30687643@N00
comment._content: The Coal Quay was a waterfilled at one time. On the 1726 map its called Newmans Quay. Most of the streets in Cork City centre were at one time part of the R. Lee and gradually covered over. Drawbridge St really had a drawbridge over what is now Patrick St www.corkpastandpresent.ie/mapsimages/corkcityinoldmaps/17...

comment.author: 52797433@N06
comment._content: Here's a modern street view. The Cornmarket centre takes up the right hand side of the street. And there's a fabulous bar/restaurant on the left called Bodega. Their pancakes with bacon and maple syrup are the perfect hangover cure :) maps.google.com/maps?q=The+Cornmarket+Centre,+Cork,+Irela...

comment.author: 52797433@N06
comment._content: The building visible at the bottom of the street (on Kyle Street) with the white accents is the Bridewell Garda station.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
Reproduced in Colm Lincoln's Steps & Steeples : Cork at the Turn of the Century, Dublin : O'Brien Press, 1981, p. 47.
"The Coal Quay - this is a part of the city amusing enough to strangers, yet far too unfashionable for the respectable citizens to take much interest in. The name seems a misnomer, as the place is some distance from the literal coal quay, and coal is not sold within its precincts ... Chiefly on Saturday evenings the place is thronged with the poorer classes of tradespeople; and then, as the crowd surges along, the excited volubility of the several vendors becomes a study curious and amusing to the tourist. The 'merchants' frequently stand up on the counter, and express the several merits of their goods in praises replete with choicest native wit, and graced with the wildest blossoms of southern rhetoric."
- Shaw's Tourists' Picturesque Guide to Killarney & Cork, London : Ward Lock & Co., 1881, p. 19, quoted in Lincoln, Steps & Steeples

comment.author: 32162360@N00
